title: 115_s1704
content: The "Veterans Visa and Protection Act of 2017" is the short title of this Act, which includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines key terms such as "crime of violence," "deported veteran," and "noncitizen." The Nationality Act defines key terms such as "Secretary," "service member," and "veteran" in relation to immigration and military service. SEC. 3. RETURN OF NONCITIZEN VETERANS REMOVED FROM THE UNITED STATES; STATUS FOR NONCITIZEN VETERANS IN THE UNITED STATES. The Secretary must establish a program to allow deported veterans and noncitizen veterans in the US to become lawful permanent residents, and cancel the removal of noncitizen veterans who meet certain requirements. The program allows deported and noncitizen veterans to adjust status to lawful permanent residents without numerical limitations. Veterans are eligible if they meet specific requirements determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may waive deportation for veterans for humanitarian reasons, family unity, or exceptional service in the United States, if they were not removed due to specific criminal convictions. The Secretary may waive deportation for veterans based on humanitarian reasons, family unity, exceptional service in the United States Armed Forces, or if it is in the public interest. SEC. 4. Protecting veterans and service members from removal, a noncitizen with a criminal conviction for a crime of violence may be removed. SEC. 5. Naturalization through service in the Armed Forces of the United States. An alien with lawful permanent resident status can naturalize through service in the US Armed Forces, with exceptions for moral character evaluation and absence periods due to removal or inadmissibility. An alien with lawful permanent resident status can access military and veterans benefits if they have not been ordered removed, removed, or voluntarily departed from the United States. The Secretary will identify cases of service members or veterans at risk of removal from the US by inquiring about their military service, requiring approval before initiating removal proceedings, and keeping records of those who have had proceedings initiated against them. The Secretary will annotate immigration records of service members or veterans identified as at risk of removal, including branch of military service and whether they served during military hostilities. The Secretary will annotate immigration records of service members or veterans, including their immigration status at enlistment, honorable service status, reasons for removal, and details of any criminal convictions. The Secretary will promulgate regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment.
